The drawbacks supplemented with ZnO such as wide band gap, immense charge carrier recombination and photo-corrosion (deactivation) during the photocatalytic reactions obfuscate for large scale applications. Accordingly, research is swiftly inclining to spotlight the ZnO as an appropriate semiconductor to many competitive metal oxides (TiO2, Bi2O3 and WO3) in the area of heterogeneous photocatalysis. In this focused review, several strategies like synthesizing with hierarchical morphology and exposed facets, impurity doping, metal deposition, integrating with other semiconductors and modifying with carbon materials which induces multifunctional properties to boost the performance of ZnO are articulated. It is presumed that the photocatalytic activity of the modified ZnO arises from the collective contribution of effective charge carrier separation, generation of surplus active free radicals coupled with striking structure-electronic properties and nature of the photocatalytic reactions. The overall findings enunciate that such amendments to ZnO are beneficial to improve structural stability and also to obtain desired features driving for various energy applications.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
As one of the realistic approach in the advanced oxidation processes, semiconductor driven heterogeneous photocatalysis functioning at the ambient conditions has reaped the paramount signature in the solar energy conversion, waste water purification and in deactivating many harmful microorganisms (Kumar and Rao 2017). In particular, this versatile green approach signifies the complete conversion of organic carbon to CO2 without leaving any secondary harmful byproducts which is indispensable for the degradation of many noxious pollutants (Kumar and Rao 2015a). As an complementary to remarkably investigated TiO2, ZnO is at the fore for energetic applications admired from its incredible physicochemical and optoelectronic properties, large exciton binding energy, favorable band edge positions, high electron mobility, simplistic preparative methods and defect rich chemistry, and can be structurally stabilized by supporting over many conducting substrates (Kumar and Rao 2015a; Lee et al. 2016; Ashkarran et al. 2010; Ashkarran, 2011). In disparity to TiO2, ZnO absorbs more fractions of light quanta and can be synthesized using various processes (physical and chemical) with divergent morphologies. In addition, few research outcomes also suggests the dynamic functioning of ZnO over TiO2 for the degradation of organic pollutants under the light illuminating conditions (Kumar and Rao 2015a; Lee et al. 2016).
Likely to other conventional photocatalysts, predominant obstacle such as massive charge carrier recombination, large band gap and photo-induced corrosion has fiddled the ZnO incompatible for many visible light

Being renewable and inexhaustible, exploiting the natural solar light as an excitation source for the photocatalysis would be very fascinating to scale this technology towards industralization. In this review, strategic steps to alter the surface-bulk structure of ZnO such as synthesis with nanostructured morphology and exposed facets, impurity doping, interfacing with other semiconductors, metallic deposition and integrating with carbon materials which are whispered to be the cornerstone for improved visible light photocatalytic activity is expatiated. The performance of modified ZnO is discussed in the light of charge carrier dynamics-generation, recombination and transfer pathways together with the participation of active species (free radicals) in the pollutant degradation reactions.
Improving the photocatalytic performance of bare ZnO
Band gap excitation of ZnO by absorbing the photons with appropriate light energy generates energetic holes in valence band (VB) and electrons in the conduction band (CB). These electron–hole pairs react with suitable adsorbed species to initiate the redox reactions or it may recombine by dissipating the excess energy as heat. In general, CB electrons trigger the dioxygen reduction to generate superoxide radicals which transforms to hydroperoxyl and hydroxyl radicals through cyclic reactions, while holes oxidize the water or adsorbed hydroxyl anion to yield hydroxyl radicals in the aqueous suspension. These active oxygenated free radicals reacts with the pollutants in the aqueous/gas phase finally resulting in the complete mineralization (Kumar and Rao 2015b, 2017; Kumar and Devi 2011; Ashkarran et al. 2009).
The effectual charge carrier separation and their redox reaction with pollutants/adsorbed species plays a decisive role in promoting the overall reaction rates, which is interreliant on various factors such as excitation source, solution pH and the presence of oxidizing agents. The band gap excitation with energetic photons (UV light, 254 nm) expels the lattice oxygen from the ZnO lattice sites and enables their participation in the degradation reaction besides generating the hydroxyl radicals driven from the H2O2 formation on the ZnO surface. Contrarily, low energy photons (UV light, 365 nm) does excite only the band gap leading to the formation of electron–hole pairs without distorting the defect structure of ZnO. The former deactivates the ZnO and deteriorates its stability in the aqueous suspension (Ali et al. 2011). Under the visible light illumination, distinct sensitized mechanisms operate depending on the nature of the adsorbate; (1) dye sensitized photocatalysis takes place wherein electron transfer takes
place from excited states of sensitizer to the CB of ZnO (Saikia et al. 2015): (2) few phenolic compounds forms surface complex with ZnO facilitating the migration of electron transfer directly from its ground state to the ZnO CB (Fig. 1) (Li et al. 2009). Although fate of transferred electrons to initiate dioxygen reduction remains same in both the pathways, surface complexation in the latter requires the effective orbital interaction between the metal (zinc ion) and ligand (phenolic compounds). Such surface complexation curtails the surface defects on ZnO and also allows to amplify the visible light utility owing to the formation of strong metal–oxygen–ligand bond. This mechanism was implicated in ‘sense and shoot’ approach during the degradation of phenolic compounds (Kamat et al. 2002). In contrast, dye sensitization process is active only till the adsorbate (dye molecules) absorbs in the visible region and operates till chromophore absorbing the visible light is strongly adsorbed on the semiconductor surface. The sensitization processes is very sensitive to solution pH and deteriorates with weakened attractive interactions between ZnO surface and sensitizer molecules.
The point of zero charge (PZC) of ZnO lies around pH 9 (Kumar and Rao 2015a). Therefore, adsorption and degradation of the pollutants will be pronounced if it exists in anionic and cationic forms at the pH conditions below and above the PZC, respectively. In addition, alkaline pH favors the generation of hydroxyl radicals from the plentiful hydroxyl anions in the solution. The relation between adsorption and degradation is not always strictly observed, as reaction rate is influenced by various factors associated with catalyst, geometry of the reactor, nature of the pollutant, excitation source etc. As widely reported, ZnO undergoes dissolution to form Zn2? ions in the acidic condition, while Zn(OH)2 and [Zn(OH)4] 2- formation at the alkaline medium restricts the ZnO based photocatalysis to propel in the pH range of 5–10 (Kumar and Rao 2015a; Anju et al. 2012). The addition of suitable electron scavengers such as H2O2, KHSO5, KBrO3 and K2S2O8 into the
semiconductor suspension promotes the degradation kinetics (Krishnakumar and Swaminathan 2011; Shukla et al. 2010). These oxidizing agents increases the degradation reactions rates through various pathways; (1) they cease the CB electrons to facilitate the direct oxidation of pollutants by the VB holes (Kumar and Devi 2011); (2) modifies the surface acid–base properties to promote the adsorption and desorption of pollutant molecules (Kumar and Rao 2015a); (3) free radicals generated from oxidants also actively renders the cleavage of covalent bonds in the pollutants (Fig. 2). Interestingly, KHSO5 on decomposition produces both sulfate and hydroxyl radicals, thus benefitting the superfluous generation of active species. These radicals although have lower oxidation potential compared to hydroxyl radicals, but are competent enough to mineralize the organic carbon through a sequence of oxidative reactions. In any case, there exists an optimum concentration for these oxidants in the aqueous suspension to promote the degradation kinetics, which corresponds to the generation of threshold level of free radicals via effective charge carrier separation (Sobana and Swaminathan 2007; Kumar and Rao 2017). Above this dosage, these acceptors quench the hydroxyl radical formation and restrain the degradation kinetics. The effects of H2O2 are not very significant as it exhibit low tendency for adsorption onto the ZnO surface. In addition, ZnO surface itself generates H2O2 under UV light illumination through the protonation of superoxide radicals. Thus, more H2O2 formed on the surface might trap the holes and also quench the generated hydroxyl radical’s generation itself (Sobana and Swaminathan 2007).
In the case of defect free ZnO, photogenerated carriers are vulnerable for surface-bulk recombination resulting in low photonic efficiency. The presence of defects such as oxygen vacancy, zinc interstitial and oxygen interstitial can temporarily inhibit the charge carrier recombination process and magnificently improve the reaction rates (Pei et al. 2013; Kayaci et al. 2014). For instance, oxygen vacancy forms energy levels below the CB edge of ZnO and,
therefore, easily traps the electron, while energy levels of interstitial oxygen defects will be just above the VB edge of ZnO and behaves as trap states for VB holes (Wang et al. 2009b). The oxygen vacancies also narrow the band gap to induce the visible light response and can be retained even at high temperature under nitrogen ambience (Liu et al. 2013; Wang et al. 2015). Recently, hydrogenated black ZnO (heating ZnO under hydrogen atmosphere) associated with large density of zinc and oxygen vacancies displayed long-wavelength absorption and excellent photocatalytic activity (Xia et al. 2014). Irrespective of synthesis methods, defects formation is habitual during the growth of ZnO nanocrystals and further investigation is imperative to reveal the influence of density and distribution of defects on the photocatalytic reactions.
The irregular morphology of defective ZnO are not beneficial for the adsorption of pollutants, and it is very difficult to recover them for subsequent use in the repeated cycles. From the view point of better reusability and channelizing the flow of charge carrier, synthesis and photocatalytic performance of ZnO hierarchical morphologies such as hollow spheres (Yu and Yu 2008), flower-like morphology (Su et al. 2016), nanorod arrays (Wang et al. 2015), nanotubes (Bojer et al. 2017), nanowires (Pomar et al. 2016), tetrapods (Mishra et al. 2015), nanoplates (Li et al. 2016a), etc. are reported in photocatalytic applications. These morphologies improve the structural stability and photoactivity through offering rich active sites for the pollutant adsorption–desorption process. Compared with various protocols, ZnO hollow spheres obtained from glucose as structure directing agent was very much fascinating as they were achieved conveniently without using any harsh reaction conditions. The carbonization of glucose and their coordinating ability with Zn2? ions followed by shrinking of core via Ostwald ripening resulted in the formation of hollow spheres (Yu and Yu 2008). The thickness of the shell may be tuned by manipulating the reaction conditions. These nanostructures intensify the absorption of photons and carrier migrates easily to the surface with minimum recombination centers. These nanostructures also provide diffusion channels for the reactants and products enabling the efficient interaction between the free radicals and pollutants/intermediates. Because of constructive geometric configuration, these nanostructure assemblies do not lose their pristine morphologies and are stable in the reaction solution with minimal aggregation which attests their exceptional resistant towards photocorrosion, and hence can be used for extended runs during the photocatalytic reactions (Kumar and Rao 2015b, 2017; Li et al. 2016b). Several ZnO nanostructures are fruitfully obtained by wet chemical methods under the mild operating conditions. The forma-
tion mechanism of these nanostructures is quite complex as
it is allied to the multiple reaction parameters such as solution pH, nature of precursors, solvents, reaction temperature/time, surfactant and templates, solution chemistry, etc. (Kumar and Rao 2014a). The formation of Zn(OH)2 and [Zn(OH)4] 2- complexes coupled with the experimental conditions plays a vital role in tuning and shaping the morphology of ZnO.
Tailoring the reactive facets (polar to non-polar ratio) of ZnO is the recent venture to attain for charge carrier separation (Kim et al. 2016; Liu et al. 2016). The change in surface atomic structure determines the rate of carrier transfer and adsorption of different oxygenated species. The ZnO consists of Zn-terminated {0001} and O-terminated {000-1} positive and negative polar surfaces, respectively. The holes generated migrate to negative polar surface inducing oxidative reactions, while electrons are trapped at positive polar surface initiating reduction pathways (Kumar and Rao 2017). The in-built polarized electric field drifts the carriers to move in opposite directions and also adsorbs more number of hydroxyl groups and oxygenated species on its surface (Kumar and Rao 2015a). Although, facile protocol to tune the facet-morphology is still underway, more investigation is needed to understand the formation mechanism, tuning the facet ratio. These faceted ZnO are expected to find its scope in photovoltaics (Chetia et al. 2015).
Strategies for visible light photocatalytic applications
Many contemporary methods such as substitutional doping with foreign ions, surface deposition with noble metals, and coupling with other semiconductors with varied band edge potentials are investigated to harvest the solar light and also to prolong the life time of photogenerated charge carriers. The doping process affects the bulk structure and changes the atomic coordination, while deposition and coupling approaches merely attributes to the change in the surface structure without altering the lattice bulk. The extent to which the visible light response is attained relies mainly on the preparation methods and the mechanisms of charge carrier transfer process are distinct for each strategy (Kumar and Rao 2017).
Doping with foreign ions
Impurity doping at the cationic/anionic sites is a promising approach to alter the structure-electronic properties of any semiconductors. ZnO is doped with alkali/alkali earth metal ions (Benhebal et al. 2012; Nouri and Yangjeh 2014), transition metal ions (Saleh and Djaja 2014),
nonmetals (Wang et al. 2016) and rare earth ions (Luo et al. 2015; Sin et al. 2014). The significant improvement in the photonic efficiency with all these dopants is successfully achieved. The following observations are largely encountered upon impurity doping; (1) change in the defect chemistry—substituting at lattice sites in the Zn–O–Zn (cationic doping) and Zn–O–O (anionic doping) framework leads to the formation of Zn–O–M. The change in the local atomic configuration modifies the electronic environment and simultaneously introduces structural defects, lattice disorder and lattice stress/strain. The segregation of these dopants along the grain boundary region inhibits the growth of crystallite size; (2) mismatch in the ionic radius between the dopant and host ion is the basis for changes in the defect chemistry. In addition, varied oxidation states of the foreign ion contributes to structural disorder to a considerable extent; for instance, doping with hypervalent ions ([?2 oxidation state) reduces the oxygen vacancy concentration and vice versa to maintain the charge neutrality in the pristine matrix. Although defects assumed to remain same with isovalent doping (like Fe2?, Mn2? and Ni2? ions), but the inevitable structural disorder due to ionic radius mismatch affects the density of surface-bulk defects (Kumar and Rao 2017). These defects can act as trap sites for the charge carriers and restrain them from recombination process and also facilitate the adsorption of molecular oxygen onto its sites during the photocatalytic process (Kumar and Devi 2011; Kumar and Rao 2017); (3) changes the band gap absorption properties—substitution at the lattice sites induces the incorporation of new energy levels to increase the density of electronic states within the pristine gap. As a result, sub band gap electronic transition originates from the band gap states to these energy levels, thus lowering the energy required for electronic transition and shifting the absorption to longer wavelengths (Fig. 3). These energy levels serves as shallow traps states for the carriers and detraps the same to adsorbed species, thereby
enhancing the interfacial charge transfer pathways and also facilitate the generation of free radicals in the solution. Contrarily, band gap widening rooting from the size quantization effects leads to blue shift in the absorption edge (Kumar and Rao 2015a).
Doping with alkali metal ions into ZnO matrix for photocatalytic purpose are dealt scarcely, but Mg2? incorporation has displayed some reliable results. The 3s character of Mg induces energy level above the CB of ZnO and hence widens the band gap energy, which increases the redox power of photogenerated charge carriers. It is to be noted that observed quantization in the band gap is purely associated with the 3s level of Mg2? and not associated from the smaller crystallite size of Mg–ZnO (Qiu et al. 2008). The substitution with transition metal ions in relevance to photocatalysis is quite ambivalent; as both beneficial and detrimental effects are reported (He et al. 2012; Yi et al. 2014). The former is attributed to the favorable modifications in the structure-electronic properties and also to the shallow trapping ability of dopant, while latter originates mainly from the ineffective doping and introduction of deep traps which might encourage the recombination process. The properties such as electronic configuration and solubility of the dopant in the ZnO matrix determine the performance of doped ZnO. The dopants with half filled configuration (Mn2? or Fe3? ions) loses its electronic stability after capturing the electron or holes. Thus, the trapped carriers are rapidly detrapped to the adsorbed species to restore its stable electronic configuration. These processes collectively prevent the recombination and promote the generation of free radicals (Kumar and Devi 2011).
On the other hand, formation of impure dopant phase can change the chemical composition of ZnO itself to deteriorate the performance (Li et al. 2014). The formation of impurity may be controlled either by lowering the annealing temperature and reducing the dopant content at the expense of crystallinity and the visible light response. With an exception to Ag? ion, most of the transition metal ions easily diffuse into the bulk of matrix to substitute the lattice sites within the limits of their solubility. Metallic silver is generally formed in the course of Ag? doping because of the larger ionic radius of Ag? ions (115 pm) compared to host Zn2? ions (74 pm). This certainly hinders their diffusion into the lattice bulk and Ag2O impure phase formed finally decomposes to metallic silver and oxygen on the ZnO surface in the course of annealing (Yıldırım et al. 2013).
The increase of surface acid–base properties, smaller crystallite size, enhanced surface area, inhibition of charge carrier recombination, enriched adsorption of pollutants on the catalyst surface are the common features observed upon doping the ZnO with rare earth ions (Kumar and Rao
2015a). The vacant ‘f’ orbitals of the rare earth ions behave as strong Lewis acid to form complexes with functional group of the pollutants (Okte 2014; Rezaei and Yangjeh 2013a, b). This promotes the concentration of pollutants on the ZnO surface and allows for the efficient interactions between the pollutants and free radicals (Kumar et al. 2015). In addition, ‘f’ orbital can transfer the electrons to adsorbed oxygen to initiate dioxygen reduction and simultaneously capture the CB electrons of ZnO to restore its electronic configuration. With an exception to La3?, other rare earth ions have improved the visible light response for ZnO (Okte 2014; Zong et al. 2014). Among the various methods of obtaining Ln–ZnO, microwave assisted (Rezaei and Yangjeh 2013a) and simple refluxing methods (Rezaei and Yangjeh 2013b) were found to be more attractive, as the protocol involved mild operating temperature and can be conveniently extended to prepare other phase pure doped materials.
The doping with metal ions usually introduces deep trap levels within the band gap states and also high doping levels cannot be attained owing to the restricted solubility of these dopants in the native matrix. To overcome these drawbacks, incorporation with non metals such as nitrogen and carbon is preferred owing to their enhanced solubility and very low energy is required for their substitution process (Zhou et al. 2009). In contrast to doping with metal ions, nitrogen/carbon substitute oxygen lattice sites to induce new energy levels just above the VB edge of ZnO. As a result, the hybridization between O 2p and N/C 2p orbitals narrows the band gap and increases the absorption edge to the visible region. It is also reported that C–ZnO exhibited absorption stretched in the range of 400–700 nm compared to N–ZnO (*400 nm) (Zhou et al. 2009). In addition, high oxidative power of C–ZnO is more beneficial as a result of downward shift in the energy band structure due to carbon doping (Liu et al. 2011). It was also suggested that amorphous ZnO accommodates the more nitrogen doping into their matrix during the substitution process under NH3 annealing and improve the photocatalytic activity compared to fully crystallized matrix. The high concentration of defects, dangling bonds and high surface energy associated with the amorphous phase facilitates the diffusion of nitrogen, and hence promotes the doping process. Contrastingly, crystallized matrix because of strong Zn–O bonds might be hard for nitrogen incorporation (Yu et al. 2013). This report is very important from the point of obtaining the high nitrogen content into the ZnO, and need to be carefully verified whether the same is applicable for other dopants and host matrices also! The exclusion of nitrogen and carbon from the lattice sites during the thermal treatment at high temperature remains a major stumbling block to fabricate thermally stable nonmetal doped ZnO (Liu et al. 2011). The doping of iodine
(Bouaifel et al. 2011), phosphorous (Xie et al. 2013), sulfur (Patil et al. 2010) and antimony (Omidi et al. 2013) also evidenced the high photocatalytic performance, but, however, more studies are required to understand the doping mechanism.
Co-doping with two or more ions as well as doping the same ion in different oxidation states improves the oxygen vacancy concentration and induced large red shift in the band gap absorption, which enables the doped ZnO to efficiently absorb more photons under visible light (Bhatia et al. 2017; Yi et al. 2014). The co-dopants or doping with varied oxidation states owns the different ability to trap the charge carriers and also introduces multiple carrier trapping sites to favor the generation of free radicals. The results of C–N–S tridoping into ZnO were striking as collective contribution from each dopant improved the photocatalytic activity (Yu et al. 2016). It is to be noted that thiourea served as single precursor for the simultaneous doping of carbon, sulfur and nitrogen. The sulfur changes its substitution mode from anionic to cationic during the course of annealing changing the defect chemistry of pristine ZnO and also the band gap absorption properties (Chen et al. 2008). The co-doping is advantageous only when both visible light response and charge carrier separation are simultaneously achieved. As the diffusivity is different for each dopant, doping depth for each impurity will definitely vary inside the lattice and that the mutual interference among the dopants in the doping process may not result in successful co-doping. These aspects need to be revisited for designing the effective codoped ZnO systems.
The existence of optimum dopant concentration to display the outstanding activity clearly reflects that there exists a balanced contribution and co-ordination among the factors such as band gap absorption, crystallite size, distribution of dopants and induced defects (Choi et al. 1994). The dopant effects are only realized when these factors contribute effectively to the photocatalytic reactions. It is to be noted that visible light responsive doped ZnO do not always certify for robust performance. The preparation method, dopant precursor/dopant concentration, annealing temperature/time and crystallinity of ZnO are the other critical parameters to obtain doped materials supplemented with desired structure-electronic properties.

sections.heading: Noble metal deposition
sections.text:
Rather than the bulk modification via doping, surface modification of ZnO is more appealing as most of the photocatalyzed reactions triggers on the catalyst surface itself. Therefore, surface structure is critical to modulate the charge carrier separation and generation of free
radicals. In this regard, noble metal deposition on the ZnO surface is quite encouraging as it tailors the both electronic properties as well as charge carrier dynamics. These deposited noble metals serves as electron sink to suppress the recombination process and surface plasmon resonance (SPR) effect of deposited metals extends the light response to longer wavelengths making the heterostructure to function under solar spectrum (Devi and Kavitha 2016). When noble metal and ZnO contacts each other, Schottky or Ohmic barrier is formed at their interfaces because of the differences in the work function of metal and semiconductor concurrently with changes in the relative position of Fermi levels. The direction of built-in electric field depend on the contact types and, therefore, impact the photocatalytic performance (Yan et al. 2013). On the other hand, distribution of metal deposits around the defect structure (oxygen vacancies) of ZnO would be more favorable, rather than their segregation on the grain boundaries. The density of chemisorbed oxygen and surface hydroxyl groups enhances upon metal deposition, accompanied with the deactivation of surface oxygen atoms that collectively improves the photostability of ZnO (Kumar and Rao 2015a, 2017). These multiple effects alter the related properties such as photo-luminescence and photocatalysis. The noble metals such as Ag, Au, Pt and Pd are frequently used, with Ag being the prime choice because of its impeachable catalytic potential, non-toxicity and highest electrical and thermal conductivity, cost-effectiveness and antibacterial activity (Devi and kavitha 2016). Moreover, silver can enhance the photocatalytic property by creating a local electric field and the optical vibration of SPR in silver can intensify this electric field. The SPR of metal nanoparticles (NPs) depends on the size, shape, local electronic environment and dielectric properties of the host matrix on which metal is deposited. These unique SPR effect shows dominating optical, electrical and catalytic properties (Jana et al. 2016).
There are four types of metal–ZnO heterojunctions that are extensively emphasized in the literature till date; (1) depositing the metal NPs onto the surface of ZnO (He et al. 2012); (2) depositing the metal on the hierarchical morphology of ZnO like nanorods (Yang et al. 2013), nanosheets (Sung et al. 2012), nanoribbons (Cheng et al. 2015), nanowires (Zhang et al. 2014a) etc.; (3) deposition of ZnO NPs on hierarchical morphology of metal (like nanowires) (Xiong et al. 2016); (4) nucleation of nanostructured ZnO onto the metal pre-designed with specific morphology (Zuo et al. 2013; Gu et al. 2009). The type (1) heterostructure normally leads to non-uniform distribution of metallic islands on the ZnO surface and, therefore, effective charge carrier separation in all the instances is very hard to expect. The type (2) composites allows more metallic NPs to decorate on the ZnO surface leading to the
high density of metal–ZnO interfaces, thus improving the rate of photocatalysis. For instance, metallic NPs can extensively decorate on the side surface and on the tip of nanorod arrays as well as can disperse on both inside and outside of the tubular morphology. In addition, nanostructure provides very high surface area and minimal aggregation among the ZnO crystallites enables the fine distribution of large density metal clusters. The case (3) involves the nucleation of ZnO NPs that are distributed on the surface of Ag nanowires, while type (4) involves the hetero epitaxial growth of ZnO nanorod arrays on Ag wires which enables larger visible light absorption and effective carrier transfer pathways accompanied with exceptional structural stability in the aqueous conditions. In addition, type (4) benefits from the morphological effects of both metal and semiconductor. Thus, ZnO@metal core@shell structure is associated with type (1) and (2), while metal@ZnO is observed with type (3) and (4) heterostructure. In the former, metal inhibits the photocorrosion of ZnO, while ZnO prevents the metal from photo-oxidation as well as from possible leaching into the aqueous solution in the latter case (Kumar and Rao 2017). The further improvement in type (1) can be easily obtained by depositing the metal nanoparticles on the mesoporous ZnO, which also provides large surface area facilitating the uniform distribution of metal NPs (Bouzid et al. 2015). It will be more meaningful if performance of these composite structures is discussed for the same probe reactions to realize the striking differences and similarities among these heterostructures.
The methods such as photo-reduction and chemical reduction are commonly used to reduce the metal ions onto the surface of ZnO. The photo-deposition is very convincing as it avoids the use of external reductants, but the adhesion of metal deposits onto the semiconductor surface is very poor. The nucleation of isolated metal NPs within the solution is the other demerit of this technique. On the other hand, NaBH4 (Fageria et al. 2014), glucose (Tian et al. 2011), sodium citrate (Li et al. 2015), ethanol (Zhai et al. 2015), dimethyl formamide (Aguirre et al. 2011), ethylene glycol (Zhang et al. 2012), hydrazine hydrate (Fageria et al. 2014), triethanol amine (Dinesh et al. 2014) and hexamethylene tetramine (Sun et al. 2012) are commonly used as reducing agents depending on the preparative methods. The most appealing was the use of phytochemicals such as pomegranate peel extract for reducing the silver ions (Kaviya and Prasad 2015). Recently, Sn (II) activation for the reduction of silver ions was also reported to fabricate stable visible light responsive heterostructure (Deng et al. 2015). The addition of reducing agents is, however, preferable, but their effect on the nucleation pathways of ZnO is still far from critical discussion and is not always justified at the large scale
preparation. The solution pH plays an important role in the reduction of metal ions in the wet chemical methods. Normally, metal ion precursor (like AgNO3) is allowed to adsorb on the ZnO nuclei/surface followed by their sequential reduction. If Ag? experience columbic repulsion from the ZnO surface at strong acidic conditions, low density of Ag would be formed on the ZnO surface and isolated nucleation of metallic silver dominates in the solution itself. Conversely, Ag? experience electrostatic interaction with negatively charged ZnO surface in the alkaline medium, but the precipitation of Zn(OH)2 retards the deposition process. Therefore, pH = PZC is more favorable for the chemical reduction of Ag on the ZnO surface as the electrical double layer is reduced because of vanished repulsive forces. Unlikely, negatively charged metal precursors (AuCl4 - or PtCl4 2-) might adsorb strongly on a positively charged ZnO in the acidic medium resulting in a high density of Au/Pt NPs (Fageria et al. 2014; Salcedo et al. 2014). Alternatively, biomolecule bovine serum albumin (Gao et al. 2011) and oil of wild ginger (Azizi et al. 2016) is also reported to reduce metallic silver and found to co-ordinate with both Ag and Zn ions, indicating their additional role as a shape controlling agent. The electrochemically active film served as a reducing medium for silver deposition by providing excess electrons and protons by biologically decomposing the sodium acetate (Ansari et al. 2013). The advantage of this protocol is that it does not include any high energy input and external reducing agents, which makes this synthesis highly recommendable to fabricate the efficient composites. The reducing media and the reduction method are very important to obtain fine tuned metal NPs.
The metallic islands traps the CB electrons from the excited ZnO under UV light, while metal NPs excites as a result of SPR effect and transfers the electron to ZnO CB under visible light. Thus, metal deposits play a dual role depending on the excitation source. The Schottky barrier facilitates the flow of electrons from ZnO to metal islands and initiates the dioxygen reduction, while the holes resided on the VB directly initiates the oxidation process under UV light. Irrespective of metals that are deposited, its size and content is essential to facilitate the unidirectional flow of electrons from CB of ZnO to metal to adsorbed oxygen (Fig. 4). If the size of metal clusters is extremely small, then its energy level will be higher than the CB of ZnO as a result of size quantization effects, while energy levels would be situated below the adsorbed oxygen for large sized metallic aggregates, with both the effects hampers to channelize the electrons for superoxide radical production (Kumar and Rao 2017). In addition, over accumulation of negatively charged metallic NPs attracts the positively charged holes enhancing the recombination pathways. In addition, metal NPs tend to aggregate at higher metallic
content which reduces the metal-ZnO interfaces and also shields the incident photons to reach the ZnO surface simultaneously diminishing the composite performance (Kumar and Devi 2011; Kumar and Rao 2015b, 2017).
The integration of metal NPs with semiconductors with dissimilar crystal structures (facets) are favorable as the synergy in the various functional properties of both the materials can be carefully exploited in the photocatalytic applications. The surface structure of ZnO is crucial for the uniform distribution of metal NPs in larger content and that the interface structure of Ag–ZnO is essential to extend the carrier life time. As several methods are available to reduce the metal ions and to fabricate metal–ZnO heterostructure, future research for improving the performance should be dealt with utmost priority.
Coupling with other semiconductors
Integrating the ZnO with other semiconductors having different band gap configuration allows the utilization of broad spectrum of solar energy and vectorial charge carrier transfer from one component to another as a result of inbuilt electric field that facilitates the charge carrier separation at the interface. In the critical view of the literature, there are only four important classes of ZnO based composite systems:
1. In the case of coupling ZnO with wide gap materials
(metal oxides), chosen semiconductor possess CB and VB edges slightly below that of ZnO band edge positions. This kind of composites will be active only under UV light, and SnO2 (or TiO2) is the most commonly used material for this coupled system (Hamrouni et al. 2014; Konyar et al. 2012). As it is well known, VB edges of anatase TiO2 and ZnO are almost same, while the electrons derived from the CB are more negative for ZnO, thus allowing only the
migration of electrons. Contrarily, migration of electrons and holes are widely accepted, which is in our assumption that VB and CB edges shifts according to the solution pH. In any case, TiO2 suppresses the photocorrosion of ZnO, while ZnO can improve the light absorption properties of the composite, as it can absorb more quanta than TiO2. The coupling with SnO2 facilitates the migration of electrons from ZnO to SnO2 and holes in the reverse direction to induce charge separation. The preparation route can either involve the hetero epitaxial growth of one semiconductor over another or by simple co-precipitation technique. This is usually followed by the thermal treatment of the composite to induce the crystallinity. The annealing temperature and time together with the composite ratio is very important to prevent the formation impure phases such as ZnTiO3 and Zn2SnO4 as a result of inter-diffusion of ions in the composite system (Konyar et al. 2012; Wang et al. 2009a). The cheap availability of precursors (zinc, tin and titanium) and facile formation of these oxides at the moderate conditions together with synergistic effects between the components spotlights their effectiveness in photocatalysis. 2. In the case of coupling ZnO with narrow gap materials,
CB and VB position of coupling semiconductor will be situated slightly above that of ZnO. The narrow gap material like CdS (Eg 2.4 eV) is a classic candidate for this type of composite. Likely to ZnO, CdS also possess wurtzite polymorph and hence integration between ZnO and CdS with similar crystal structure and atomic arrangements results in better connectivity at the atomic level with reduced density of interfacial defects. This composite can be activated under the broad range of solar spectrum (UV–visible portion) and that ZnO serves as electron collector, as electrons migrates from CdS to CB of ZnO (Jana et al. 2014). The hole generated at the CdS VB site might not have enough potential to generate hydroxyl radicals, and hence directly attacks the dye molecules. The photocorrosion of metal sulfide due to sulfur deposition is the main drawback of the composite. Generally, CdS is grown on crystallized ZnO via chemical solution route, which involve the addition of Cd2? ion followed by their reaction with sulfur source. The reaction between Cd2? and S2- ions is very fast and hence bulk CdS is always formed and sometimes it separates into the solution phase resulting very low content of CdS on the ZnO surface. To avoid these drawbacks, dimethyl formamide solvent is preferred as it releases S2- ions very slowly and, therefore, size tunable CdS can be neatly obtained on the ZnO surface (Villani et al. 2012). Alternatively, ZnO is surface functionalized
with acidic groups (such as citric acid) which allows preferential anchoring of Cd2? ions followed by the addition of sulfur source leading to the formation of small sized CdS NPs (Khanchandani et al. 2012). More studies are definitely needed to study the effect of change in the sulfur precursor as well as the reaction medium on the formation of CdS and their interfacial contacts with ZnO. The ZnO were also grown on CdS crystals successfully under mild wet chemical approach (Jana et al. 2014). Although this strategy inhibits the corrosion of CdS, the formation of CdO impurity in the course of annealing cannot be ignored. Another homologous system of this composites is UV light active ZnO–ZnS, as it can be obtained from simple sulifidation of ZnO itself. Zinc being the common cation in this composite, addition of extra chemical reagents is generally avoided and formation of impure junctions is not expected (Sadollahkhani et al. 2014). The recent reports on coupling with Ag-based semiconductors like AgI (Agjekandy and Yangjeh 2015), AgBr (Shi et al. 2014) Ag2SO4 (Cao et al. 2015), AgCl (Lamba et al. 2015), Ag3PO4 (Dong et al. 2014), Ag3VO4 (Kiantazh and Yangjeh 2015) and Ag2CO3 (Xiang et al. 2016) as cocatalyst with ZnO was more attractive as Ag based compounds are conveniently achieved by simple precipitation method and are facile to tailor their size-shape-morphology at ambient conditions. The ternary composites AgCl/Ag/ZnO (Alamdari et al. 2015) and Ag/Ag2WO4/ZnO (Pirhashemi and Yangjeh 2017) also exhibits significant activity owing to the cooperative effects arising from the deposited metal clusters. Barring AgCl and Ag2WO4, other Ag-based semiconductors are visible light absorption candidates. The dye sensitized photocatalysis and SPR effect of deposited Ag were found to be the crucial factor for visible light photocatalytic activity of Ag/Ag2WO4/ZnO, while both ZnO and Ag2WO4 served as passive electron sinks (Fig. 5). The major issue associated with Ag-based semiconductors are the leaching of Ag ions and their simultaneous deposition as Ag nanoparticles in the course of photocataytic reactions. The size of metal aggregates is difficult to control and hence their effects on the degradation kinetics might be beneficial or detrimental. These aspects require careful study which would be essential to fabricate efficient heterojunctions utilizing silver compounds. 3. Tricomponents system involves the integration of ZnO
with two different semiconductors possessing varied absorption properties, band edge positions and carrier mobility. This system not only allows carrier transfer among all the components, but also facilitates full
utilization of incident photons. The ZnO–TiO2–SnO2 (Yang et al. 2012) and ZnO-Degussa P25 (anatase ? rutile) (Wang et al. 2008) are the unique systems so far reported with the metal oxides towards UV light photocatalysis. Recently, ternary systems like ZnO–AgBr–Ag2CrO4 (Pirhashemi and Yangjeh 2015), ZnO–Ag2S–CdS (Chen et al. 2016) together with magnetic materials such as ZnO–AgI–Fe3O4 (Gohari and Yangjeh 2016a), ZnO–Ag3VO4–Fe3O4 (Gohari and Yangjeh 2015), Fe3O4–ZnO–CoWO4 (Gohari and Yangjeh 2017) and Fe3O4–ZnO–CuWO4 (Gohari and Yangjeh 2016b) are also applied in wastewater purification under visible light. The ZnO serves as electron sink and other coupled systems acts as visible light harvesting medium. The presence of Fe3O4 is beneficial in separating the composite magnetically for recycling purpose. These ternary systems are citing more interest as many semiconductors that are inactive by itself becomes a part of photocatalytic systems after integrating with ZnO. 4. Rather than the conventional charge transfer which
deteriorates the redox potential of charge carriers after the inter-component charge transfer process, Z-scheme pathways brandish to be more strategic as CB electrons in ZnO recombines with holes generated in the VB of integrated component thus sparing the electrons and holes with high redox potentials for photocatalytic reactions. The hydrogen evolution from ZnO–CdS system is purely ascribed to prolonged carrier lifetime as a result of Z-scheme process (Fig. 6), which is otherwise not possible in the conventional systems (Wang et al. 2009c). From this approach, it is possible to avoid the photocorrosion of metal sulfides photocatalyst, as VB holes engages in recombination with CB electrons of integrated component. Such Z-scheme process can also be mediated through deposited gold nanoparticles between ZnO and CdS and this system is more useful conversion of -NO2 to -NH2 group (Zhang et al. 2016).
Another interesting candidate is visible light responsive g– C3N4 (Eg 2.7 eV), an analogue of graphite which improves the stability and photoactivity of ZnO. The g–C3N4 can be obtained from various precursors rich in carbon and nitrogen such as melamine, urea, thiourea and dicyanoamine (Ong et al. 2016). The formation of chemically bonded interface between g–C3N4 and ZnO originates from condensation reaction between the triazine amino group and the surface hydroxyl groups of ZnO. The g–C3N4 sensitizes the composite allowing the electron transfer to take place from CB of g–C3N4 to ZnO CB, while holes resided at g–C3N4 VB have very weak potential to generate hydroxyl radicals. Thus, electron driven hydroxyl and superoxide radicals play a major role in the
degradation mechanism in this composite. The carbon doping is also possible during the hybridization of these carbon forms, which facilitates the intense visible light absorption (Qin et al. 2017). The composites with mesoporous g–C3N4 was found to be more beneficial compared to bulk g–C3N4, as the mesoporous structure enables the ZnO surface to absorb more incident photons and their larger surface area facilitates the adsorption and desorption of pollutant molecules during the course of photocatalytic reactions (Le et al. 2017; Vignesh
et al. 2015). Further research is still underway to combine ZnO with modified g–C3N4 for photocatalysis.
The major obstacle with the composite system is the complex preparative route wherein hydrolysis rate of each precursor, gel formation, precipitation of each phase and the mutual interference of central metal ions severely affects the crystallization process (Kumar and Rao 2014a). As many chemicals are used in various steps, removing the surface impurities during the washing process becomes quite tedious which might also result in the aggregation of the crystallized products. The fraction of the individual component in the coupled systems to display the maximum performance can vary for each probe reactions. There have been scarce reports on the simultaneous formation of the composite with one-pot approach. The thermal treatment poses another hurdle as a result of inter-diffusion among the components and also formation of impure phases, which changes the energetic and spatial distribution of interfacial defects as well as the alignment of energy band structures and space charge width, thus deactivating the heterojunctions for desired applications (Kumar and Rao 2014b, 2017).
Modification with carbon materials
Being the most abundant element, carbon in its various atomic configurations (0D, 1D and 2D structures) with tailored structure-electronic properties and high mechanical stability has boosted the fabrication of functional hybrid ZnO–carbon materials in major energy applications (Han et al. 2014). The commercial availability and its exceptional ability to serve as substrate for the growth of numerous semiconductors with diverse morphology is an added advantage to its extensive usage. Graphene has attracted enormous interest and they are consistently coupled with ZnO to improve the photocatalytic performance for many probe reactions. In particular, unique 2D structure and surplus p-electrons provides a suitable platform for the growth of finely dispersed ZnO with engineered defects and varied morphologies. The ZnO–graphene (or reduced graphene oxide-RGO) composite can be conveniently fabricated by wet chemical methods such as solvothermal (Moussa et al. 2016), microwave irradiation (Zhu et al. 2017), combined sol–gel and hydrothermal (Fu et al. 2013) together with physical techniques such as electrospinning (An et al. 2014), electrodeposition (Wei et al. 2013) and liquid arc discharge methods (Ashkarran and Mohammadi 2015). The growth of ZnO over graphene sheet under these aforementioned methods further suggests the adoptability of carbon materials as spectacular substrate under various reaction conditions. Graphene have excellent carrier mobility, conductivity, and thermal stability and electron accepting-transporting properties and also improves the spectral range of the ZnO. In addition, graphene can enhance the adsorption of pollutants on the composite surface through the interaction of their p–p conjugated systems with the aromatic pollutants (Lv et al. 2012; Han et al. 2014; Fu et al. 2013; An et al. 2014; Wei et al. 2013; Ashkarran and Mohammadi 2015). Under UV light, ZnO serves as good electron donor, while graphene acts as better electron collectors, which are rapidly detrapped to the adsorbed oxygen. Contrarily, electron migration proceeds from sensitized dye to ZnO CB via graphene sheets under visible light. The ZnO can also prevent the restacking of graphene sheets during the photocatalytic reactions, which enables to maintain structural integrity of the composite. The introduction of graphene oxide also induces the formation of oxygen vacancies in the ZnO to improve the visible light response (Pan et al. 2014). The modification of this composite with noble metal deposition and coupling with CdS not only improves the visible light response but also channelizes the charge carrier to flow along the specified path which prevents them from recombination process (Wen et al. 2013; Pawar and Lee 2014). The ternary composite ZnO–graphene–Au was more efficient
for the conversion of nitrobenzene to aniline under UV light. The unidirectional electrons transfer from ZnO to Au NPs via graphene sheets prevailed during the excitation process. The graphene might have promoted the adsorption of nitrobenzene, while Au NPs suppressed the electron– hole recombination (Roy et al. 2013).
Similar to graphene, single or multiwalled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs/MWCNTs) and fullerenes also serves as better electron acceptors and promotes the photocatalytic activity (Liu et al. 2014; Fu et al. 2008). In fact, electrons flow freely throughout the structure of CNTs without any scattering from atoms or defects (ballistic transport). The novel version of the ZnO–carbon materials is the design of ZnO–RGO–CNTs ternary composite, wherein electron transfers from ZnO to RGO to CNT resulting in magnificent charge carrier separation (Lv et al. 2012). The synthesis involved the growth of ZnO on dispersed RGO and CNTs under microwave irradiation (100 C, 30 min). The ZnO nanorods were dispersed on graphene sheets and CNTs weave between RGO sheets and ZnO nanorods providing the better interfacial structure among the blended components. The incorporation of CNTs into RGO forms a conductive network structure to connect the gaps between the RGO nanosheets (Fig. 7). Such a conjugated network promotes the electrical conductivity and provides rapid electronic conducting channels for photocatalysis (Lv et al. 2012). The fraction of both ZnO and carbon materials are essential to maintain composite integrity and also to display high performance. Above certain limit, composite activity deteriorates due to the fact that these carbon materials screens the incident photons reaching the catalyst surface and also forms poor interfacial contacts with ZnO.

Carbon quantum dots (CQDs) also sensitize the ZnO under visible light and its luminescent properties convert the longer wavelength light (absorbed) to shorter region (emitted), enabling the band gap excitation of ZnO to generate surplus charge carriers (Yu et al. 2012). The CQDs decorated on ZnO surface forms dyade-like structure providing an easy access to charge carrier transfer pathways and the performance is highly sensitive on the number of quantum dot layers (Li et al. 2013). The ternary composites associated with ZnO and carbon materials needs to be investigated for its more beneficial application in photocatalysis.
Similarly, surface modification of ZnO with amorphous/ activated and carbon nanofibers also enhances the degradation reactions (Wang et al. 2007; Samadi et al. 2013; Zhang et al. 2014b). However, improvements are largely associated with the adsorption of pollutants and their influence on optical properties and charge carrier dynamics are less understood. The precursors rich in carbon content and that are facile to carbonization process (glucose, ethanol, citric acid and furfural) are normally chosen to decorate thin layer of amorphous carbon onto the ZnO surface. These precursors alters the nucleation, growth and also the morphology of ZnO owing to their solubility in the aqueous medium. The extent of carbonization and thickness of carbon shell depends on the annealing temperature together with the content of the carbon precursor. The surface coated carbon prevents the structural destruction and dissolution of ZnO during the photocatalysis as they facilitate the direct attack of VB holes to the pollutants. In addition, adsorption of the pollutant heavily concentrates on the catalyst surface additionally contributing to the efficacy of the process. The bifunctional carbon–ZnO material involving deposited and doped carbon was achieved in mesoporous carbon/C–ZnO composite that was active under visible light (Wang et al. 2014). This composite was obtained by one step process in CO2-expanded
ethanol solution. The CO2 played important roles such as; (1) assisted the uniform doping of carbon; (2) it offered the carbonate and bicarbonate anions which co-ordinated to zinc cation and facilitates the uniform deposition of surface carbon. In addition, carbonate anion served as template for the formation of mesoporous carbon. This approach to synthesize the ZnO with surface and bulk carbon can be extended to other metal oxides such as TiO2, WO3 and Bi2O3. The expulsion of carbon at high temperature calcination and also under UV light illumination is a major setback for this type of composite together with the photocatalytic decomposition of graphene in the semiconductor suspension further provides a room to develop stable carbon materials-ZnO hybrid systems (Radich et al. 2014; Park et al. 2009).

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
ZnO nanomaterials has grasped massive interest towards photocatalytic applications because of its striking similarities with benchmark titania in structure-electronic properties. However, inadequacies such as large band gap, structural instability and high degree of charge carrier recombination in the ZnO inhibit them from widespread applications. The modification through various approaches as outlined encompasses all the features such as longer wavelength response, effective charge carrier separation and improved structural stability that are pre-requisite for robust performance. The type of modifications and nature of modifiers dictates the charge carrier generation–separation–recombination dynamics (Table 1).
Unfortunately, all the deficits associated cannot be accomplished in a single strategy and are often as observed as compensating effects; for instance, doping definitely improves the visible light response but their effects on photocatalytic performance might be detrimental too.

Alternatively, synthesizing with hierarchical morphology might channelize the charge carrier migration but without improvement in the optical properties. Although, synergy in combining these strategies such as doping–deposition, deposition–coupling, and so on are recently ventured, but the efficiency realized is still far from industrial applications. The situation is an impasse to attain all these features even with multiple modifications, as materials properties are quite sensitive to preparative conditions. Since the ZnO performance is coupled to the various parameters, balancing the merits and demerits in each strategy and tuning the selectivity of the model reactions is always a challenging task. In addition, most of the research is focused on wurtzite phase and investigations on other polymorphs of ZnO (cubic and rock salt) are rather scarce. With the critical analysis of published literature, we strongly believe that ZnO–carbon materials composites would be ideal to reach the industrial standards as large surface area, in situ carbon doping, enhanced adsorption of pollutants and stable heterojunctions are simultaneously realized. Despite many hurdles ahead, modified ZnO is nevertheless foreseen as an interesting nanomaterial for various green energy applications.

metadata.abstractText: Zinc oxide photocatalyst with multifaceted and tunable structure-electronic properties has garnered foremost relevance in the wastewater purification. The drawbacks supplemented with ZnO such as wide band gap, immense charge carrier recombination and photo-corrosion (deactivation) during the photocatalytic reactions obfuscate for large scale applications. Accordingly, research is swiftly inclining to spotlight the ZnO as an appropriate semiconductor to many competitive metal oxides (TiO2, Bi2O3 and WO3) in the area of heterogeneous photocatalysis. In this focused review, several strategies like synthesizing with hierarchical morphology and exposed facets, impurity doping, metal deposition, integrating with other semiconductors and modifying with carbon materials which induces multifunctional properties to boost the performance of ZnO are articulated. It is presumed that the photocatalytic activity of the modified ZnO arises from the collective contribution of effective charge carrier separation, generation of surplus active free radicals coupled with striking structure-electronic properties and nature of the photocatalytic reactions. The overall findings enunciate that such amendments to ZnO are beneficial to improve structural stability and also to obtain desired features driving for various energy applications.
